Emulating Full Client Participation: A Long-Term Client Selection Strategy for Federated Learning

Qingming Li, Juzheng Miao, Puning Zhao, Li Zhou, Shouling Ji, Bowen Zhou, Furui Liu This work was supported by National Key R&D Program of China (2023ZD0121400, 2023ZD0121401). (Corresponding author: Furui Liu)Qingming Li, Shouling Ji are with the College of Computer Science and Technology at Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang, 310027, China. E-mail: jzmiao22@cse.cuhk.edu.hk.Puning Zhao, Li Zhou, Furui Liu are with Zhejiang Lab, Hangzhou, Zhejiang, 311000, China. Abstract

Client selection significantly affects the system convergence efficiency and is a crucial problem in federated learning. Existing methods often select clients by evaluating each round individually and overlook the necessity for long-term optimization, resulting in suboptimal performance and potential fairness issues. In this study, we propose a novel client selection strategy designed to emulate the performance achieved with full client participation. In a single round, we select clients by minimizing the gradient-space estimation error between the client subset and the full client set. In multi-round selection, we introduce a novel individual fairness constraint, which ensures that clients with similar data distributions have similar frequencies of being selected. This constraint guides the client selection process from a long-term perspective. We employ Lyapunov optimization and submodular functions to efficiently identify the optimal subset of clients, and provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence ability. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed strategy significantly improves both accuracy and fairness compared to previous methods while also exhibiting efficiency by incurring minimal time overhead.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Client Selection, Individual Fairness, Coreset Selection, Lyapunov Optimization

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) facilitates collaborative model training without the necessity of sharing local data [1, 2], and is widely used in various domains [3, 4, 5]. In FL, model parameters or gradient updates are frequently exchanged between the central server and participating clients, leading to substantial communication overhead. To address the challenge posed by the limited bandwidth, a common approach is to select a subset of clients for local training, which reduces the communication costs compared with involving all clients [6, 7]. However, in heterogeneous scenarios, different selection strategies lead to distinct optimization trajectories, and an improper client selection strategy can cause the optimization trajectory to deviate seriously from the optimal one, significantly hindering the model performance. Therefore, a critical challenge is to develop an effective client selection strategy that reduces the communication overhead while ensuring model convergence.

In most cases, the global models generated by full client participation are considered the gold standard or benchmark. This is because they represent models trained on the entire dataset available across all clients, offering a comprehensive reference point for evaluating model performance. Building upon this understanding, we propose an intuitive strategy where clients are selected in a manner that ensures the optimization trajectory closely resembles that achieved with full client participation over the long term. We refer to this strategy as the long-term client selection strategy. This strategy yields two key advantages. First, by emulating the optimization trajectory of full client participation, it aims to achieve comparable performance. Moreover, it reduces communication overhead by involving only a subset of clients in the process.

Our Goal. In this work, we investigate the three questions: 1) what principles should be followed to implement this strategy; 2) how to mathematically formulate this strategy and provide a fast solution; and 3) is this strategy more effective than existing methods? To answer the first question, we propose two crucial principles to be followed.

Principle I: In each round, the data distribution generated by the selected subset of clients should closely resemble the data distribution of the full client participation. For example, in Fig. 1 (a), clients collaboratively train an image classification model, where each client has images of only one kind of animal, and three clusters exist in their data distributions. Due to limited bandwidth, the server is required only to select three clients in each round. In this case, as shown in Fig. 1 (b), the ideal strategy is to select one client from each cluster instead of three clients from the same cluster. This ensures that the data distribution resulting from the subset of selected clients serves as a reliable estimation of that from the full set of clients. However, in real-world applications, the clustering pattern in data distributions may be unknown or non-existent. Therefore, the key challenge here is to determine the subset of clients that best approximates the full client set without imposing extensive assumptions on their data distributions.

However, if only Principle I is followed and client selection is performed by evaluating each round individually, there is a risk that the same subset of clients may be consistently selected across multiple rounds, while others may have minimal opportunities for selection. This phenomenon is indeed observed in our experimental results. In such cases, the system may accurately predict outcomes for frequently selected clients but makes inaccurate or biased predictions for those rarely selected, resulting in degradation of the global model‚Äôs performance and ineffective convergence. Furthermore, these seldom-selected clients may perceive unfair treatment and lose motivation to participate, ultimately endangering the sustainability of the federated system.

To mitigate this problem, we propose Principle II, which guides client selection across multiple rounds from a long-term perspective. Principle II: In multi-round selection, clients with similar data distributions should have similar frequencies of being selected. For example, as illustrated in Fig. 1, clients 1, 2, and 3 should share similar selection frequencies, as should clients 4 and 5, while the frequencies for clients 1 and 4 may differ. This principle aligns with the concept of individual fairness (IF) in central machine learning [8], which posits that similar instances or individuals in a dataset should yield similar predictions or outcomes. In our work, we refer to this principle as the individual fairness constraint. Here, the key challenge is to quantify the similarity between clients in terms of data distribution and selection frequency, respectively, and further formulate individual fairness mathematically.

This proposed individual fairness offers two key benefits. First, as illustrated in Fig. 1 (c), it promotes the diversity of selected clients across multiple rounds and reduces model prediction bias. Furthermore, existing fair federated learning approaches often utilize a uniform sampling constraint [9, 10, 11] to ensure similar selection probabilities for all clients. However, this uniform approach may compromise selection performance, as it disregards the heterogeneous data distribution among clients. In contrast, our proposed fairness constraint specifically targets clients with similar data distributions. Thus, it allows for varying selection frequencies among clients with heterogeneous data distributions, such as clients 1 and 4 in Fig. 1. This flexibility enables the individual constraint to accommodate the data heterogeneity without compromising selection performance in single rounds.

Limitation of Prior Works. To address the client selection problem, a common approach is the random selection strategy [1]. Recent works have proposed various improvements, including contribution-based [12, 1, 13, 14, 15], loss-based [16, 17, 18], and cluster-based methods [19, 20]. However, these methods typically evaluate each round individually and fail to select clients from a long-term perspective, potentially leading to model biases and fairness issues. Additionally, the clustering pattern in data distributions may be unknown or non-existent, making the application of cluster-based methods challenging. Furthermore, fair federated learning has discussed collaborative fairness [13, 15, 21], group fairness [22, 22] and performance fairness [23, 24], where performance fairness aligns most closely with our objectives. Existing fair federated learning approaches often utilize a uniform sampling constraint [9, 10, 11] to ensure similar selection probabilities for all clients. However, it disregards the heterogeneous data distribution among clients and requires their selection probabilities to be uniformly similar. This may hinder the identification of the optimal subset of clients that best approximates the full set of clients.

In this study, we propose a novel long-term client selection strategy in federated learning (LongFed), designed to emulate the model performance achieved with full client participation. In a single round, we perform client selection by minimizing the estimation error between a representative subset of clients and the full set of clients. In multi-round selection, we propose a novel individual fairness constraint to promote the diversity of selected clients without compromising selection performance in single rounds. Subsequently, we formulate the client selection problem as a time-averaged optimization function and simplify it using Lyapunov optimization from control theory. In addition, leveraging the submodular nature of the optimization function, we propose a fast greedy algorithm to find the optimal subset of clients in each round. The convergence of the proposed strategy is also analyzed. We conduct extensive experiments to validate the proposed LongFed strategy. First, the proposed strategy effectively guides the system to converge along a trajectory similar to that of full client participation. Second, it outperforms prior works in terms of both accuracy and fairness. Last, the proposed strategy introduces minimal time overhead compared to the random selection strategy. Our contributions are as follows.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We propose a novel long-term client selection strategy designed to guide the system to converge along a trajectory similar to that of full client participation. This strategy does not require extensive assumptions on the data distribution.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We identify and address an issue that has been rarely discussed in previous works, i.e., the frequency of selecting clients with similar distributions. We propose an individual fairness criterion to mathematically formulate this issue and employ Lyapunov optimization to solve it.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We provide an extensive theoretical analysis of the convergence ability of the proposed strategy.

II Related Work

Existing literature relevant to our work can be broadly categorized into two groups: client selection methods and fairness issues in federated learning.

II-A Client Selection in Federated Learning

In vanilla federated learning systems [1], the random selection strategy is commonly employed to choose clients. Recent works have proposed various improvements, including contribution-based [12, 1, 13, 14, 15], loss-based [16, 17, 18], and cluster-based methods [19, 20].

The first type focuses on evaluating client contributions, where clients with higher contributions are assigned higher selection probabilities. One commonly used metric is the local data size, and clients with larger datasets are considered to have higher contributions [12, 1]. Another approach involves employing the Shapley value [25] from game theory, which calculates the average marginal model improvement of each client over all possible coalitions [13, 14, 15]. Clients that result in larger model performance improvements are regarded as making larger contributions and are assigned higher probabilities of selection. Additionally, some methods evaluate the similarity between the local model at each client and the aggregated global model at the server. Clients with higher similarities are considered to bring little improvement to the global model and are thus assigned lower selection probabilities in subsequent training epochs [21, 26].

The second type involves selecting clients based on their training losses. These methods consider that clients with higher training losses may struggle to effectively fit their local data. As a result, they assign higher selection probabilities or weights to these clients [16, 17]. FedCor is a representative work in loss-based approaches that employs Gaussian processes to model the loss correlations between clients and selects clients with a substantial reduction in expected global loss [18]. Furthermore, recognizing that clients may contain similar and redundant information, a diverse strategy is proposed to choose a subset of clients that can best represent the full client set [27].

The third approach involves a cluster-based strategy. Recognizing that clients may have different data distributions or have their own learning tasks, these clustering-based approaches divide the clients into several clusters. Clients within the same cluster exhibit similar data distributions, whereas those in different clusters may display significant variations in their data distributions. In aggregation, the server randomly selects a client from each cluster. In this cluster-based paradigm, FedCG leverages a graph neural network to capture gradient sharing across multiple clusters [19]. Moreover, IFCA addresses the cluster identification problem by determining the cluster membership of each client and optimizes each of the cluster models in a federated learning framework [20].

However, most of these methods select clients by evaluating each round individually, thus failing to optimize a series of client subsets from a long-term perspective. These limitations could cause potential model biases and fairness issues, ultimately resulting in lower convergence efficiency. Furthermore, if the clustering pattern among clients is known, the long-term client selection problem becomes straightforward: simply selecting one client randomly from each cluster in every communication round [20]. However, in practical scenarios, the clustering pattern is usually unknown or, in some cases, does not exist. This limitation renders cluster-based methods ineffective for solving the long-term client selection problem.

II-B Fairness in Federated Learning

There are three types of fairness in federated learning: collaborative fairness, group fairness, and performance fairness. Collaborative fairness emphasizes that clients who make larger contributions should be rewarded with correspondingly larger rewards, and the assessment of client contributions is a key challenge. Client contribution evaluation methods have been discussed in Section II-A in the context of contribution-based client selection methods.

Group fairness [28], also known as algorithmic fairness, emphasizes that model outputs should not unfairly discriminate against vulnerable or underrepresented groups, such as minorities, women, or the aged [29]. FairFed [22] serves as one of the representative works of addressing this concern. In FairFed, both global fairness metrics at the server and local fairness metrics at each client are defined. These metrics assess disparities in opportunities among different groups. FairFed then dynamically adjusts aggregation weights at each round based on the discrepancies between global and local fairness metrics, which effectively mitigates the biases towards sensitive attributes [22].

Performance fairness refers that the model should produce similar performance across all clients, where the uniformity of performance is commonly used as the metric for evaluation [30, 31]. Various approaches have emerged to achieve performance fairness. For example, in [24], fairness is defined by assigning uniform weight to each client and introduced as an additional constraint in the optimization function. Besides, [23] identifies a trade-off between model robustness and fairness, and proposes a personalized framework to inherently achieve both fairness and robustness benefits. Moreover, several works study the fairness issue by considering that the probability of being selected is similar for all clients [9, 10, 11].

However, the three types of fairness described above cannot effectively address the fairness issue outlined in Principle II. While collaborative fairness and group fairness focus on different aspects compared to our work, performance fairness aligns most closely with our objectives. In these works [9, 10, 11], the uniform sampling method ensures a similar probability of being selected for all clients. However, we argue that it is unsuitable for achieving the long-term client selection strategy. This is because the uniform sampling method disregards the heterogeneous data distribution among clients. Consequently, it may hinder the identification of the optimal subset of clients that best approximates the data distribution of full client participation.

III The Proposed Optimization Function

In this section, we begin with an introduction to the federated learning system. Next, we illustrate the client selection in a single round and across multiple rounds, followed by the proposed long-term optimization function. Last, we apply Lyapunov optimization to transform and simplify the optimization function.

III-B The Optimization Function

III-B1 Client Selection in a Single Round

In a single round, we identify the subset of clients that best approximates the data distribution of the full set of clients. Specifically, we evaluate the estimation error between the aggregated gradient obtained from the client subset ùïätsuperscriptùïäùë°\mathbb{S}^{t} and the aggregated gradient obtained from the full client set ‚Ñï‚Ñï\mathbb{N}. A small estimation error indicates that the subset of selected clients can effectively represent the data distribution of the full client set. Mathematically, we formulate it as

(2)

Here, ‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}) represents the gradient of the iùëñi-th client, ‚àëi‚àà‚Ñï‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)subscriptùëñ‚Ñï‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}) is the aggregated gradient on the full client set ‚Ñï‚Ñï\mathbb{N}, and ‚àëj‚ààùïätŒ∏jt‚Äã‚àáfj‚Äã(ùíòt)subscriptùëósuperscriptùïäùë°superscriptsubscriptùúÉùëóùë°‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptùíòùë°\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t}) denotes the weighted sum of gradients on the client subset ùïätsuperscriptùïäùë°\mathbb{S}^{t}. Then, selecting a subset of clients that best approximates the data distribution of the full client set is equivalent to choosing a subset that minimizes the estimation error defined in Eq. (2).

Notice that the formation in Eq. (2) is similar to the concept of data coreset introduced in [32]. The data coreset involves selecting a weighted small sample of training data to approximate the gradient of the whole training data set. It is important to highlight that data coreset is commonly employed to enhance training efficiency in centralized machine learning scenarios [33, 34], while our focus is on optimizing client selection to reduce communication bandwidth in decentralized and federated scenarios. Moreover, data coreset is typically utilized for a one-time data selection process, while client selection in federated learning is a long-term process carried out across multiple rounds. The long-term optimization nature introduces new challenges, such as fairness issues and potential model biases introduced in Section I.

Although using Disti,j‚Äã(t‚àí1)subscriptDistùëñùëóùë°1\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t-1) to approximate Disti,j‚Äã(t)subscriptDistùëñùëóùë°\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t) may introduce biases when either client is not selected, experimental results demonstrate that there are minimal impacts on the model convergence. This can be attributed to two reasons. First, there are limited variations in gradients between successive communication rounds. Moreover, the individual fairness constraint proposed in Section III-B2 ensures that each client has the opportunity of being selected and the corresponding Disti,j‚Äã(t)subscriptDistùëñùëóùë°\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t) can be updated. (3) to make DUB‚Äã(ùïät)DUBsuperscriptùïäùë°\text{DUB}(\mathbb{S}^{t}) solvable.

III-B2 Client Selection Across Multiple Rounds

In our work, we propose a novel fairness constraint to guide the client selection process across multiple rounds. This constraint asserts that clients with similar data distributions should have similar frequencies of being selected.

To formulate the fairness constraint, we establish metrics to measure the similarity between a pair of clients in terms of their data distributions and the frequencies of being selected, respectively. First, we use Disti,j‚Äã(t)subscriptDistùëñùëóùë°\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t) in Eq. (4) to measure the similarity of the data distribution and use Eq. (5) to compute its value. Second, let xi,tsubscriptùë•ùëñùë°x_{i,t} represent whether the iùëñi-th client is selected in the tùë°t-th round, with xi,t=1subscriptùë•ùëñùë°1x_{i,t}=1 if i‚ààùïätùëñsuperscriptùïäùë°i\in\mathbb{S}^{t} and xi,t=0subscriptùë•ùëñùë°0x_{i,t}=0 otherwise. We use

pi=1T‚Äã‚àët=1Tùîº‚Äã(xi,t).subscriptùëùùëñ1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëáùîºsubscriptùë•ùëñùë°\displaystyle p_{i}=\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}(x_{i,t}). (6)

to evaluate the frequency of a client iùëñi being selected throughout the total TùëáT rounds. Note that {xi,t}subscriptùë•ùëñùë°\{x_{i,t}\} forms a stochastic process, and the expectation operation ùîºùîº\mathbb{E} is applied in Eq. (6). Given two clients i,j‚àà‚Ñïùëñùëó‚Ñïi,j\in\mathbb{N}, we use |pi‚àípj|subscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó|p_{i}-p_{j}| to quantify the difference between their frequencies of being selected.

Building on Disti,j‚Äã(t)subscriptDistùëñùëóùë°\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t) and pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}, we employ the œµ‚Äã-‚ÄãŒ¥italic-œµ-ùõø\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF framework utilized in [35, 36] to quantify the fairness constraint. We evaluate a client selection strategy at the end of the TùëáT-th communication round. Specifically, given œµ,Œ¥‚â•0italic-œµùõø0\epsilon,\delta\geq 0, a client selection strategy is of individual fairness if for every pair of clients i,j‚àà‚Ñïùëñùëó‚Ñïi,j\in\mathbb{N} with Disti,j‚Äã(T)‚â§œµsubscriptDistùëñùëóùëáitalic-œµ\text{Dist}_{i,j}(T)\leq\epsilon, the difference in their frequencies of being selected, namely, pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} and pjsubscriptùëùùëóp_{j}, should not exceed Œ¥ùõø\delta. The mathematical formulation of œµ‚Äã-‚ÄãŒ¥italic-œµ-ùõø\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF is provided in Definition 1, and the impact of parameter selection for œµitalic-œµ\epsilon and Œ¥ùõø\delta is discussed in Section V-C.

Definition 1.

(œµ‚Äã-‚ÄãŒ¥italic-œµ-ùõø\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF). Consider œµ,Œ¥‚â•0italic-œµùõø0\epsilon,\delta\geq 0, a client selection strategy is said to be of individual fairness if

‚àÄi,j‚àà‚Ñï,Disti,j‚Äã(T)‚â§œµ‚áí|pi‚àípj|‚â§Œ¥.formulae-sequencefor-allùëñùëó‚ÑïsubscriptDistùëñùëóùëáitalic-œµ‚áísubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëóùõø\displaystyle\forall\,i,j\in\mathbb{N},\,\,\text{Dist}_{i,j}(T)\leq\epsilon\,\,\Rightarrow\,\,|p_{i}-p_{j}|\leq\delta. (7)

Note that œµ‚Äã-‚ÄãŒ¥italic-œµ-ùõø\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF requires examining Eq. (7) for all pairs of clients, leading to significant computational overhead and rendering subsequent optimization challenging. To address this issue, we propose to determine a reference client i‚ãÜsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜi^{\star} for each client iùëñi, which exhibits the largest difference in the frequency of being selected among clients whose gradient distances are less than œµitalic-œµ\epsilon. i‚ãÜ=argmaxDisti,j‚Äã(T)‚â§œµ‚Äã|pi‚àípj|,‚àÄj‚àà‚Ñï.formulae-sequencesuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜsubscriptargmaxsubscriptDistùëñùëóùëáitalic-œµsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëófor-allùëó‚Ñï\displaystyle i^{\star}=\text{argmax}_{\text{Dist}_{i,j}(T)\leq\epsilon}\,|p_{i}-p_{j}|,\;\forall\;j\in\mathbb{N}. (8)

Then, given a client iùëñi and its reference client i‚ãÜsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜi^{\star}, a client selection strategy is certified as œµ‚Äã-‚ÄãŒ¥italic-œµ-ùõø\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF if

|pi‚àípi‚ãÜ|‚â§Œ¥,‚àÄi‚àà‚Ñï.formulae-sequencesubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜùõøfor-allùëñ‚Ñï\displaystyle|p_{i}-p_{i^{\star}}|\leq\delta,\quad\forall\;i\in\mathbb{N}. (9)

By introducing the reference client in Eq. (8), the evaluation of œµ‚Äã-‚ÄãŒ¥italic-œµ-ùõø\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF is simplified from examining Eq. (7) for pairs of clients i,j‚àà‚Ñïùëñùëó‚Ñïi,j\in\mathbb{N} to evaluating Eq. (9) for individual clients i‚àà‚Ñïùëñ‚Ñïi\in\mathbb{N}. This reduction in the number of variables facilitates further optimization.

III-B3 The Optimization Function

Building on the estimation error in Eq. (2) and the individual fairness constraint in Eq. (9), we formulate the client selection strategy as an optimization problem. The objective is to select a series of subsets {ùïä1,‚ãØ,ùïäT}superscriptùïä1‚ãØsuperscriptùïäùëá\{\mathbb{S}^{1},\cdots,\mathbb{S}^{T}\} with |ùïät|=Ksuperscriptùïäùë°ùêæ|\mathbb{S}^{t}|=K that minimize the expected estimation error over all TùëáT rounds while adhering to the individual fairness constraint. That is,

(P1) min{ùïä1,‚ãØ,ùïäT}‚ÄãlimT‚Üí+‚àû1T‚Äã‚àët=1Tùîº‚Äã[DUB‚Äã(ùïät)],subscriptsuperscriptùïä1‚ãØsuperscriptùïäùëásubscript‚Üíùëá1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëáùîºdelimited-[]DUBsuperscriptùïäùë°\displaystyle\min_{\{\mathbb{S}^{1},\cdots,\mathbb{S}^{T}\}}\;\lim_{T\to+\infty}\frac{1}{T}\,\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}\left[\text{DUB}(\mathbb{S}^{t})\right], (10)
s.t.Eq. (9).s.t.Eq. (9)\displaystyle\qquad\textrm{s.t.}\quad\quad\text{Eq. \eqref{equ:client_star_IF}}.

However, directly solving the optimization function in Eq. (10) is infeasible. The optimization objective and constraints, particularly pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} in Eq. (9), are presented in a time-averaged form. That is, these values are determined by averaging over all TùëáT rounds, which can only be accomplished at the end of training. In contrast, federated learning requires clients to be selected online in each round. This misalignment poses a practical implementation challenge. In our work, the solution to address this misalignment is proposed in Section III-C.

III-C Problem Transformation Under Lyapunov Optimization

To solve P1 in Eq. (10), we leverage Lyapunov optimization, a technique from control theory used to analyze the stability of dynamic systems [37, 9]. The main idea behind Lyapunov optimization is to break down the long-term time-averaged constraints in the optimization problem into constraints that can be adhered to in each communication round. This allows us to optimize the objective function directly in each round without violating the constraints specific to that round. Furthermore, by ensuring that these constraints are adhered to in each round, we can automatically achieve compliance with the long-term time-averaged constraints at the end of the TùëáT round. By leveraging Lyapunov optimization, the problem stated as P1 in Eq. (10) is ultimately converted into the problem P3 in Eq. (23), which can be efficiently solved online in each communication round. Details of problem transformation are described below.

Before employing Lyapunov optimization, we remove the absolute value sign from the constraint in Eq. (9) and rephrase it as two equivalent constraints,

1T‚Äã‚àët=1Tùîº‚Äã(xi,t‚àíxi‚ãÜ,t)‚àíŒ¥‚â§0,‚àÄi‚àà‚Ñï,formulae-sequence1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëáùîºsubscriptùë•ùëñùë°subscriptùë•superscriptùëñ‚ãÜùë°ùõø0for-allùëñ‚Ñï\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}(x_{i,t}-x_{i^{\star},t})-\delta\leq 0,\;\forall\,i\in\mathbb{N}, (11)
1T‚Äã‚àët=1Tùîº‚Äã(‚àíxi,t+xi‚ãÜ,t)‚àíŒ¥‚â§0,‚àÄi‚àà‚Ñï.formulae-sequence1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëáùîºsubscriptùë•ùëñùë°subscriptùë•superscriptùëñ‚ãÜùë°ùõø0for-allùëñ‚Ñï\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}(-x_{i,t}+x_{i^{\star},t})-\delta\leq 0,\;\forall\,i\in\mathbb{N}. (12)

Lyapunov optimization typically involves three steps [37]. First, a virtual queue is defined for each time-averaged constraint. This step converts the time-averaged constraints into stability constraints for virtual queues. Second, a Lyapunov function is defined based on virtual queues, and the Lyapunov drift is introduced. This step breaks down the time-averaged constraints into requirements for Lyapunov drift in each communication round. Finally, the Lyapunov drift is integrated into the optimization objective, allowing us to minimize both the Lyapunov drift and the optimization objective simultaneously. In the following, we illustrate how to transform problem P1 using these three steps.

First, we define two virtual queues, namely Zi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëçùëñùë°Z_{i}(t) for the constraint in Eq. (11) and Qi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëÑùëñùë°Q_{i}(t) for the constraint in Eq. (12), for all clients i‚àà‚Ñïùëñ‚Ñïi\in\mathbb{N}. Specifically, these queues are initialized as Zi‚Äã(0)=0subscriptùëçùëñ00Z_{i}(0)=0 and Qi‚Äã(0)=0subscriptùëÑùëñ00Q_{i}(0)=0, and updated according to the following rule

Zi‚Äã(t+1)=max‚Å°{Zi‚Äã(t)+xi,t‚àíxi‚ãÜ,t‚àíŒ¥,0},subscriptùëçùëñùë°1subscriptùëçùëñùë°subscriptùë•ùëñùë°subscriptùë•superscriptùëñ‚ãÜùë°ùõø0\displaystyle Z_{i}(t+1)=\max\left\{Z_{i}(t)+x_{i,t}-x_{i^{\star},t}-\delta,0\right\}, (13)
Qi‚Äã(t+1)=max‚Å°{Qi‚Äã(t)‚àíxi,t+xi‚ãÜ,t‚àíŒ¥,0}.subscriptùëÑùëñùë°1subscriptùëÑùëñùë°subscriptùë•ùëñùë°subscriptùë•superscriptùëñ‚ãÜùë°ùõø0\displaystyle Q_{i}(t+1)=\max\left\{Q_{i}(t)-x_{i,t}+x_{i^{\star},t}-\delta,0\right\}.

By the introduction of Zi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëçùëñùë°Z_{i}(t) and Qi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëÑùëñùë°Q_{i}(t), we have Theorem 2, which converts the long-term constraints on xi,tsubscriptùë•ùëñùë°x_{i,t} in Eq. (11) and (12) into the stability constraints for Zi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëçùëñùë°Z_{i}(t) and Qi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëÑùëñùë°Q_{i}(t). The proof of Theorem 2 is provided in the supplementary file.

Theorem 2.

The constraints in Eq. (11) and (12) hold if Zi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëçùëñùë°Z_{i}(t) and Qi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëÑùëñùë°Q_{i}(t) remain stable, that is,

limT‚Üí+‚àûùîº‚Äã[Zi‚Äã(T)]T=0,and‚ÄãlimT‚Üí+‚àûùîº‚Äã[Qi‚Äã(T)]T=0.formulae-sequencesubscript‚Üíùëáùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëçùëñùëáùëá0andsubscript‚Üíùëáùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëÑùëñùëáùëá0\displaystyle\lim_{T\to+\infty}\frac{\mathbb{E}[Z_{i}(T)]}{T}=0,\;\text{and}\;\lim_{T\to+\infty}\frac{\mathbb{E}[Q_{i}(T)]}{T}=0. (14)

To make Zi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëçùëñùë°Z_{i}(t) and Qi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëÑùëñùë°Q_{i}(t) remain stable, an intuitive approach is to bound the increase of these queues in each round so that they could not grow to infinity. Based on this intuition, in our work, we define a global queue Œò‚Äã(t)Œòùë°\Theta(t), which stores the state of Zi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëçùëñùë°Z_{i}(t) and Qi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëÑùëñùë°Q_{i}(t) for all clients. That is,

Œò‚Äã(t)‚âú[Z1‚Äã(t),‚ãØ,Zn‚Äã(t),Q1‚Äã(t),‚ãØ,Qn‚Äã(t)].‚âúŒòùë°subscriptùëç1ùë°‚ãØsubscriptùëçùëõùë°subscriptùëÑ1ùë°‚ãØsubscriptùëÑùëõùë°\displaystyle\Theta(t)\triangleq\left[Z_{1}(t),\cdots,Z_{n}(t),Q_{1}(t),\cdots,Q_{n}(t)\right]. (15)

Second, following Lyapunov optimization, we define the Lyapunov function [37] as

L‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))‚âú12‚Äã‚àëi=1N[Zi2‚Äã(t)+Qi2‚Äã(t)],‚âúùêøŒòùë°12superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëçùëñ2ùë°superscriptsubscriptùëÑùëñ2ùë°\displaystyle L\left(\Theta(t)\right)\triangleq\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left[Z_{i}^{2}(t)+Q_{i}^{2}(t)\right], (16)

which represents the sum of the squares of all elements in Œò‚Äã(t)Œòùë°\Theta(t). Then, the increase of Œò‚Äã(t)Œòùë°\Theta(t) from the communication round tùë°t to (t+1)ùë°1(t+1) is formulated as

Œî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))‚âúùîº‚Äã[L‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t+1))‚àíL‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))|Œò‚Äã(t)],‚âúŒîŒòùë°ùîºdelimited-[]ùêøŒòùë°1conditionalùêøŒòùë°Œòùë°\displaystyle\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right)\triangleq\mathbb{E}\left[L\left(\Theta(t+1)\right)-L\left(\Theta(t)\right)|\Theta(t)\right], (17)

which is called Lyapunov drift [37]. If the drift Œî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))ŒîŒòùë°\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) remains sufficiently small in each round, the constraints in Eq. (11) and Eq. (12) will be satisfied after TùëáT rounds. That is, introducing Œî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))ŒîŒòùë°\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) allows us to break down the time-averaged constraints in Eq. (11) and Eq. (12) into the specific requirements for Œî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))ŒîŒòùë°\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) in each communication round.

At last, to ensure that Œî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))ŒîŒòùë°\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) remains sufficiently small, a straightforward method to combine the optimization objection with the drift Œî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))ŒîŒòùë°\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right), and minimize both simultaneously. Mathematically, in our work, the optimization problem in Eq. (10) is transformed into

(P2)‚Äãminùïät(1‚àíV)‚ãÖŒî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))+V‚ãÖDUB‚Äã(ùïät)(P2)subscriptsuperscriptùïäùë°‚ãÖ1ùëâŒîŒòùë°‚ãÖùëâDUBsuperscriptùïäùë°\displaystyle\text{(P2)}\;\min_{\mathbb{S}^{t}}\quad(1-V)\cdot\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right)+V\cdot\text{DUB}(\mathbb{S}^{t}) (18)

with |ùïät|=Ksuperscriptùïäùë°ùêæ|\mathbb{S}^{t}|=K as a constraint, where VùëâV is a predefined trade-off factor. Note that the expectation notation ùîºùîº\mathbb{E} is dropped since we are only concerned with a single communication round.

However, solving P2 in Eq. (18) still presents two challenges. First, determining i‚ãÜsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜi^{\star} requires the information about pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}, which is not available until the end of training. To address the issue, we calculate the frequency of a client iùëñi being selected up to the tùë°t-th round, denoted as pi‚Äã(t)=1t‚Äã‚àëk=1txi,tsubscriptùëùùëñùë°1ùë°superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùë°subscriptùë•ùëñùë°p_{i}(t)=\frac{1}{t}\sum_{k=1}^{t}x_{i,t}. Then, we determine the reference client in the tùë°t-th round by

it‚ãÜ=argmaxDisti,j‚Äã(t)‚â§œµ‚Äã|pi‚Äã(t)‚àípj‚Äã(t)|,‚àÄj‚àà‚Ñï.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜùë°subscriptargmaxsubscriptDistùëñùëóùë°italic-œµsubscriptùëùùëñùë°subscriptùëùùëóùë°for-allùëó‚Ñï\displaystyle i^{\star}_{t}=\text{argmax}_{\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t)\leq\epsilon}|p_{i}(t)-p_{j}(t)|,\;\forall\,j\in\mathbb{N}. (19)

In our experiment, we replace the reference client i‚ãÜsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜi^{\star} in Eq. (8) with it‚ãÜsubscriptsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜùë°i^{\star}_{t} in Eq. (19), thus it can be determined using information available up to the tùë°t-th round.

Additionally, because the computation of Œî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))ŒîŒòùë°\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) requires information about L‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t+1))ùêøŒòùë°1L\left(\Theta(t+1)\right), which is not available in the current round tùë°t. To overcome this issue, we derive an upper bound for Œî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))ŒîŒòùë°\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) using Theorem 3 and minimize the upper bound instead. The proof is provided in the supplementary file.

Theorem 3.

Define

mi,t=xi,t‚àíxit‚ãÜ,t‚àíŒ¥,and‚Äãni,t=‚àíxi,t+xit‚ãÜ,t‚àíŒ¥,formulae-sequencesubscriptùëöùëñùë°subscriptùë•ùëñùë°subscriptùë•subscriptsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜùë°ùë°ùõøandsubscriptùëõùëñùë°subscriptùë•ùëñùë°subscriptùë•subscriptsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜùë°ùë°ùõø\displaystyle m_{i,t}=x_{i,t}-x_{i^{\star}_{t},t}-\delta,\;\text{and}\;n_{i,t}=-x_{i,t}+x_{i^{\star}_{t},t}-\delta, (20)

then Œî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))ŒîŒòùë°\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) is bounded by

Œî‚Äã(Œò‚Äã(t))‚â§B+‚àëi=1N[Zi‚Äã(t)‚Äãmi,t+Qi‚Äã(t)‚Äãni,t],ŒîŒòùë°ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅdelimited-[]subscriptùëçùëñùë°subscriptùëöùëñùë°subscriptùëÑùëñùë°subscriptùëõùëñùë°\displaystyle\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right)\leq B+\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left[Z_{i}(t)m_{i,t}+Q_{i}(t)n_{i,t}\right], (21)

where BùêµB is a constant.

Based on Theorem 3, the problem P2 in Eq. (18) is transformed into

minùïät‚Å°(1‚àíV)‚Äã‚àëi=1N[Zi‚Äã(t)‚Äãmi,t+Qi‚Äã(t)‚Äãni,t]+V‚ãÖDUB‚Äã(ùïät).subscriptsuperscriptùïäùë°1ùëâsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅdelimited-[]subscriptùëçùëñùë°subscriptùëöùëñùë°subscriptùëÑùëñùë°subscriptùëõùëñùë°‚ãÖùëâDUBsuperscriptùïäùë°\displaystyle\min_{\mathbb{S}^{t}}\;(1-V)\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left[Z_{i}(t)m_{i,t}+Q_{i}(t)n_{i,t}\right]+V\cdot\text{DUB}(\mathbb{S}^{t}). (22)

Substituting DUB‚Äã(ùïät)DUBsuperscriptùïäùë°\text{DUB}(\mathbb{S}^{t}) by Eq. (3) and moving the sum sign outside of the minimum sign, the problem in Eq. (22) is equivalent to

(P3)+V‚ãÖ‚à•‚àáfi(ùíòt)‚àí‚àáfj(ùíòt)‚à•},\displaystyle\text{(P3)}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad+V\cdot\big{\|}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}\Big{\}},

where Zi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëçùëñùë°Z_{i}(t) and Qi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëÑùëñùë°Q_{i}(t) are defined in Eq. (13), mi,tsubscriptùëöùëñùë°m_{i,t} and ni,tsubscriptùëõùëñùë°n_{i,t} are defined in Eq. (20), and VùëâV is a hyperparameter that balances the optimization function and the fairness constraint. With an appropriate VùëâV, the solution in Eq. (23) can infinitely approximate the optimal solution in Eq. (18) [38]. In the following, we select clients by minimizing G‚Äã(ùïät)ùê∫superscriptùïäùë°G(\mathbb{S}^{t}) in Eq. (23) in each round.

IV The Proposed LongFed

IV-A The Client Selection Strategy

The optimization problem in Eq. (23) is NP-hard as it involves calculating the value of G‚Äã(ùïät)ùê∫superscriptùïäùë°G(\mathbb{S}^{t}) for N!K!‚Äã(N‚àíK)!ùëÅùêæùëÅùêæ\frac{N!}{K!(N-K)!} subsets, where !! denotes the factorial function [39]. To address this issue, we exploit the submodular nature of G‚Äã(ùïät)ùê∫superscriptùïäùë°G(\mathbb{S}^{t}).

Specifically, a set function g:2‚Ñï‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëî‚Üísuperscript2‚Ñï‚Ñùg:2^{\mathbb{N}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is submodular if for every A‚äÜB‚äÜ‚Ñïùê¥ùêµ‚ÑïA\subseteq B\subseteq\mathbb{N} and i‚àà‚Ñï\Bùëñ\‚Ñïùêµi\in\mathbb{N}\backslash B it holds that g‚Äã(A‚à™{i})‚àíg‚Äã(A)>g‚Äã(B‚à™{i})‚àíg‚Äã(B)ùëîùê¥ùëñùëîùê¥ùëîùêµùëñùëîùêµg(A\cup\{i\})-g(A)>g(B\cup\{i\})-g(B). One typical example of a submodular function is the facility location function [40]. Suppose we aim to select locations from a set of positions ‚Ñï={1,‚Ä¶,N}‚Ñï1‚Ä¶ùëÅ\mathbb{N}=\{1,\ldots,N\} to open facilities and to serve a collection of KùêæK users. If a facility is located at position jùëój, the service it provides to user iùëñi is quantified by Mi,jsubscriptùëÄùëñùëóM_{i,j}. Each user is assumed to select the facility with the highest service, and the total service provided to all users is modeled by the set function

f‚Äã(ùïä)=‚àëi=1mmaxj‚ààùïä‚Å°Mi,j,ùëìùïäsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösubscriptùëóùïäsubscriptùëÄùëñùëó\displaystyle f(\mathbb{S})=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\max_{j\in\mathbb{S}}M_{i,j}, (24)

where f‚Äã(‚àÖ)=0ùëì0f(\emptyset)=0. If Mi,j‚â•0subscriptùëÄùëñùëó0M_{i,j}\geq 0 for all i,jùëñùëói,j, then f‚Äã(ùïä)ùëìùïäf(\mathbb{S}) is a monotone submodular function. By introducing an auxiliary element eùëíe, the set function G‚Äã(ùïät)ùê∫superscriptùïäùë°G(\mathbb{S}^{t}) in Eq. (23) is transformed into

G¬Ø‚Äã(ùïät)=G‚Äã({e})‚àíG‚Äã(ùïät‚à™{e}),¬Øùê∫superscriptùïäùë°ùê∫ùëíùê∫superscriptùïäùë°ùëí\displaystyle\overline{G}(\mathbb{S}^{t})=G(\{e\})-G(\mathbb{S}^{t}\cup\{e\}), (25)

which is a facility location function and has a submodular nature. G¬Ø‚Äã(ùïät)¬Øùê∫superscriptùïäùë°\overline{G}(\mathbb{S}^{t}) measures the decrease in the value of G‚Äã(ùïät)ùê∫superscriptùïäùë°G(\mathbb{S}^{t}) associated with the set ùïätsuperscriptùïäùë°\mathbb{S}^{t} compared to that associated with just the auxiliary element eùëíe. Without loss of generality, we set the auxiliary element as e=1ùëí1e=1. Consequently, minimizing G‚Äã(ùïät)ùê∫superscriptùïäùë°G(\mathbb{S}^{t}) in Eq. (23) is equivalent to maximizing G¬Ø‚Äã(ùïät)¬Øùê∫superscriptùïäùë°\overline{G}(\mathbb{S}^{t}) in Eq. (25).

Prior studies show that the greedy algorithm is an effective solution for finding the maximum value of a submodular function [41, 39]. Following this greedy algorithm, we propose a strategy to select clients in the tùë°t-th round, as outlined in Algorithm 1. The proposed strategy starts with an empty set ùïä0t=‚àÖsuperscriptsubscriptùïä0ùë°\mathbb{S}_{0}^{t}=\emptyset, and initializes a candidate set as ‚Ñô0=‚Ñïsubscript‚Ñô0‚Ñï\mathbb{P}_{0}=\mathbb{N} (Line 3). In an iteration k‚àà[0,K‚àí1]ùëò0ùêæ1k\in[0,K-1], we first determine the reference client it‚ãÜsubscriptsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜùë°i^{\star}_{t} for client i‚àà‚Ñôkùëñsubscript‚Ñôùëòi\in\mathbb{P}_{k}, and compute mi,tsubscriptùëöùëñùë°m_{i,t} and ni,tsubscriptùëõùëñùë°n_{i,t} with xi,t=1subscriptùë•ùëñùë°1x_{i,t}=1 if i‚ààùïäktùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùïäùë°ùëòi\in\mathbb{S}^{t}_{k}, and similarly for xit‚ãÜ,tsubscriptùë•subscriptsuperscriptùëñ‚ãÜùë°ùë°x_{i^{\star}_{t},t} (Line 5-6). Next, we calculate G¬Ø‚Äã(ùïäkt‚à™{i})¬Øùê∫superscriptsubscriptùïäùëòùë°ùëñ\overline{G}(\mathbb{S}_{k}^{t}\cup\{i\}) for all clients i‚àà‚Ñôkùëñsubscript‚Ñôùëòi\in\mathbb{P}_{k}, and identify the client imaxsubscriptùëñmaxi_{\text{max}} with the maximum value (Line 7-8). Subsequently, the client imaxsubscriptùëñmaxi_{\text{max}} is removed from ‚Ñôksubscript‚Ñôùëò\mathbb{P}_{k} and added to the subset ùïäktsuperscriptsubscriptùïäùëòùë°\mathbb{S}_{k}^{t} (Line 9). This iteration continues until KùêæK clients are selected. The complexity of the algorithm is O‚Äã(K‚ÄãN)ùëÇùêæùëÅO(KN).

Based on the client selection strategy in Algorithm 1, we further present the proposed federated training algorithm, as outlined in Algorithm 2. First, the server initializes the queues Zi‚Äã(0)subscriptùëçùëñ0Z_{i}(0) and Qi‚Äã(0)subscriptùëÑùëñ0Q_{i}(0), along with the model parameter ùíò0superscriptùíò0\bm{w}^{0} (Line 3). Subsequently, the server selects the subset of clients ùïätsuperscriptùïäùë°\mathbb{S}^{t} (Line 5-9). If the communication round t=0ùë°0t=0, all clients are selected; otherwise, the server selects KùêæK clients according to Algorithm 1. The server then sends the model parameter ùíòtsuperscriptùíòùë°\bm{w}^{t} to the selected clients, and these clients perform local training and send the gradients back to the server (Line 10-11). The server updates Zi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëçùëñùë°Z_{i}(t) and Qi‚Äã(t)subscriptùëÑùëñùë°Q_{i}(t) according to Eq. (13), and aggregates these results to obtain the model parameter ùíòt+1superscriptùíòùë°1\bm{w}^{t+1} according to Eq. (1). The iteration is repeated until completing the TùëáT rounds.

IV-B Convergence Analysis

We provide a theoretical analysis to demonstrate the convergence ability of the proposed client selection strategy. The analysis uses FedAvg as the aggregation method, and it can be extended to other federated optimization methods as well. To implement the theoretical analysis, we establish six assumptions regarding the local models and data distribution heterogeneity among clients.

First, based on the effective greedy selection strategy in Algorithm 1, we assume that the estimation error between the client subset and the full client set (Eq. (2)) is small and can be quantified by a variable œÅùúå\rho, as stated in Assumption 1. This assumption has also been studied in the context of data coreset selection [32] and client selection methods [27]. Note that œÅùúå\rho is used as a measure to characterize the quality of the estimation, and the analysis holds for any œÅ<‚àûùúå\rho<\infty.

Assumption 1. At each communication round tùë°t, we assume that the gradient aggregated from the selected subset of clients can provide a good approximation of the gradient aggregated from the full set, i.e.,

‚Äñ‚àëi‚àà‚Ñï‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àí‚àëj‚ààùïätŒ∏jt‚Äã‚àáfj‚Äã(ùíòt)‚Äñ‚â§œÅ.normsubscriptùëñ‚Ñï‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°subscriptùëósuperscriptùïäùë°superscriptsubscriptùúÉùëóùë°‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptùíòùë°ùúå\displaystyle\left\|\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\right\|\leq\rho. (26)

Next, we outline the assumptions regarding local models f1,‚ãØ,fNsubscriptùëì1‚ãØsubscriptùëìùëÅf_{1},\cdots,f_{N} and their gradients ‚àáf1‚Äã(ùíòt),‚ãØ,‚àáfN‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àásubscriptùëì1superscriptùíòùë°‚ãØ‚àásubscriptùëìùëÅsuperscriptùíòùë°\nabla f_{1}(\bm{w}^{t}),\cdots,\nabla f_{N}(\bm{w}^{t}), as stated in Assumption 2-5. These assumptions are standard and widely used in the federated optimization literature [42, 43, 18, 27].

Assumption 2. f1,‚ãØ,fNsubscriptùëì1‚ãØsubscriptùëìùëÅf_{1},\cdots,f_{N} are all LùêøL-smooth. Formally, for all ùíóùíó\bm{v} and ùíòùíò\bm{w}, we have

fk‚Äã(ùíó)‚â§fk‚Äã(ùíò)+(ùíó‚àíùíò)T‚Äã‚àáfk‚Äã(ùíò)+L2‚Äã‚Äñùíó‚àíùíò‚Äñ22.subscriptùëìùëòùíósubscriptùëìùëòùíòsuperscriptùíóùíòùëá‚àásubscriptùëìùëòùíòùêø2superscriptsubscriptnormùíóùíò22\displaystyle f_{k}(\bm{v})\leq f_{k}(\bm{w})+(\bm{v}-\bm{w})^{T}\nabla f_{k}(\bm{w})+\frac{L}{2}\|\bm{v}-\bm{w}\|_{2}^{2}. (27)

Assumption 3. f1,‚ãØ,fNsubscriptùëì1‚ãØsubscriptùëìùëÅf_{1},\cdots,f_{N} are all Œºùúá\mu-strongly convex. Formally, for all ùíóùíó\bm{v} and ùíòùíò\bm{w}, it holds

fk‚Äã(ùíó)‚â•fk‚Äã(ùíò)+(ùíó‚àíùíò)T‚Äã‚àáfk‚Äã(ùíò)+Œº2‚Äã‚Äñùíó‚àíùíò‚Äñ22.subscriptùëìùëòùíósubscriptùëìùëòùíòsuperscriptùíóùíòùëá‚àásubscriptùëìùëòùíòùúá2superscriptsubscriptnormùíóùíò22\displaystyle f_{k}(\bm{v})\geq f_{k}(\bm{w})+(\bm{v}-\bm{w})^{T}\nabla f_{k}(\bm{w})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\bm{v}-\bm{w}\|_{2}^{2}. (28)

Assumption 4. The variance of gradients for fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} is bounded for i‚àà‚Ñïùëñ‚Ñïi\in\mathbb{N}. Formally, letting Œ±itsuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëñùë°\alpha_{i}^{t} be a data sample randomly chosen from the local dataset of the client iùëñi, we have

ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòit,Œ±it)‚àí‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòit)‚Äñ]‚â§B2.ùîºdelimited-[]norm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùõºùëñùë°‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëñùë°subscriptùêµ2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{t},\alpha_{i}^{t})-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{t})\|\right]\leq B_{2}. (29)

Assumption 5. The expected squared norm of gradients is uniformly bounded, that is,

ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòit,Œæit)‚Äñ]‚â§B3.ùîºdelimited-[]norm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùúâùëñùë°subscriptùêµ3\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{t},\xi_{i}^{t})\|\right]\leq B_{3}. (30)

Furthermore, we introduce the term ŒìŒì\Gamma in Assumption 6 to quantify the data heterogeneity among clients. If the data distribution among clients is independently and identically distributed, then ŒìŒì\Gamma approaches zero as the number of clients grows. Conversely, if the data distribution is heterogeneous, the magnitude of ŒìŒì\Gamma reflects the degree of heterogeneity.

Assumption 6. Let f‚ãÜsuperscriptùëì‚ãÜf^{\star} and fi‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëñ‚ãÜf_{i}^{\star} be the minimum values of fùëìf and fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}, respectively. We consider the degree of data heterogeneity to be bounded, that is,

Œì=‚Äñf‚ãÜ‚àí‚àëi=1NŒ∏i‚Äãfi‚ãÜ‚Äñ‚â§B4.Œìnormsuperscriptùëì‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùúÉùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëñ‚ãÜsubscriptùêµ4\displaystyle\Gamma=\|f^{\star}-\sum_{i=1}^{N}\theta_{i}f_{i}^{\star}\|\leq B_{4}. (31)

Based on these assumptions, the proposed client selection strategy is demonstrated to converge to the global optimal parameter ùíò‚ãÜsuperscriptùíò‚ãÜ\bm{w}^{\star} at a rate of ùí™‚Äã(1/t)ùí™1ùë°\mathcal{O}(1/t) for heterogeneous data settings, as stated in Theorem 4. The proof is provided in the supplementary file. The convergence rate ùí™‚Äã(1/t)ùí™1ùë°\mathcal{O}(1/t) is the same as existing client selection methods [27, 18, 43].

Theorem 4.

Under Assumptions 1-6, we have

ùîº‚Äã‚Äñùíò‚ãÜ‚àíùíòt‚Äñ22‚â§ùí™‚Äã(1/t)+ùí™‚Äã(œÅ).ùîºsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptùíò‚ãÜsuperscriptùíòùë°22ùí™1ùë°ùí™ùúå\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\bm{w}^{\star}-\bm{w}^{t}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\mathcal{O}(1/t)+\mathcal{O}(\rho). (32)

The term œÅùúå\rho encodes the estimation error in Eq. (2). When more clients are selected in a communication round, the subset of selected clients can better approximate the data distribution of the full client set, then the term œÅùúå\rho is smaller. Particularly, œÅùúå\rho becomes zero when all clients are selected in each round, i.e., K=NùêæùëÅK=N. We also analyze the impact of varying KùêæK empirically and propose an adaptive client selection method [44]. However, to reduce communication overhead, the number of selected clients is usually less than the total number of available clients, i.e., K<NùêæùëÅK<N. In this case, œÅùúå\rho remains a non-vanishing term. In experiments, we observe that the proposed client selection strategy guides the system to converge along a trajectory similar to that of full client participation, but there exists a non-diminishing solution bias dependent on œÅùúå\rho. This observation is consistent with our theoretical analysis.

V Experiment

V-A Experimental Settings

We consider the cross-device federated learning scenario where a large number of clients exist, each with limited computational power. In our experiments, we fix the number of clients at N=100ùëÅ100N=100 and employ FedAvg [1] as the aggregation method. The proposed client selection strategy is evaluated on two datasets, FMNIST [45] and CIFAR-10 [46]. Following the approach in [18], we opt for basic and small-scale models to accommodate the clients‚Äô restricted computational resources. Specifically, for the FMNIST dataset, we utilize a multilayer perception (MLP) with two hidden layers as the global model. For CIFAR-10, our global model adopts a convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture consisting of three convolutional layers, with the outputs of these layers fed into an MLP layer. Further details on training and hyperparameter settings can be found in the supplementary file.

We explore four data partitioning methods, including an independently and identically distributed (IID) approach and three heterogeneous approaches. In the IID approach, we randomly partition the dataset into NùëÅN parts, with each client assigned one part. We select K=5ùêæ5K=5 clients in each round. Three heterogeneous data partitioning approaches are as follows.

(i) 1 Shard Per Client (1SPC). Following the setting in [1], we divide the dataset into NùëÅN shards, ensuring that data within a shard shares the same label. We randomly assign a shard to each client so that a client has data with only one label. This is the most heterogeneous case. In this case, we select K=10ùêæ10K=10 clients in each round.

(ii) 2 Shards Per Client (2SPC). Similar to the 1SPC setting, the dataset is partitioned into 2‚ÄãN2ùëÅ2N shards, where data within each shard shares the same label. Clients are randomly assigned two shards, where most clients have data with two labels (two shards with different labels), while a few clients have data with only one label (two shards with the same label). In this case, we set K=5ùêæ5K=5 in each round.

(iii) Dirichlet Distribution (Dir). We partition the dataset based on a Dirichlet distribution parameterized by a concentration variable Œ±ùõº\alpha, where a smaller value of Œ±ùõº\alpha indicates higher heterogeneity. In our work, we set Œ±=0.8ùõº0.8\alpha=0.8. Under this setting, clients have data with all labels, but the data size of each label varies among clients. We determine the data size of each label for each client following the analysis in [47, 18]. In this case, we choose K=5ùêæ5K=5 clients in each round.

Note that the 1SPC and 2SPC scenarios address label shift heterogeneity, while the Dir scenario accounts for heterogeneity in both labels and dataset size. Furthermore, apart from the assumption of a fixed number of clients (KùêæK) to be selected, we also explore the impact of varying KùêæK and propose an adaptive method to determine its value. Details of the adaptive method can be found in [44].

We conduct the experiments five times using different randomized initial conditions and present the average results. In our experiments, we set Œ¥=0.1ùõø0.1\delta=0.1 , œµ=0.3italic-œµ0.3\epsilon=0.3, and V=0.9ùëâ0.9V=0.9 for FMNIST, and Œ¥=0.05ùõø0.05\delta=0.05, œµ=0.05italic-œµ0.05\epsilon=0.05, V=0.7ùëâ0.7V=0.7 for CIFAR-10. We compare the proposed LongFed with three baseline methods: (1) the random selection strategy (Random) [1]; (2) active client selection strategy (AFL), where clients with higher training losses have higher probabilities of being selected [16]; (3) power-of-choice strategy (Powerd), where clients are selected based on the power of dùëëd choices load balancing strategy [17]. These methods are commonly used as baselines in [18, 27]. Additionally, we compare our method with the full client participation method (Full) with K=100ùêæ100K=100.

V-B Experimental Results

V-B1 Convergence Analysis

The experimental results under the IID scenario are presented in Fig. 2, and the results under three heterogeneous data partitioning methods are presented in Fig. 3. In Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, the xùë•x axis represents the communication round, and the yùë¶y axis displays the test accuracy of the global model. For a clearer comparison, we apply the moving average rule [48] with a sliding window size of 10 to smooth the results.

Fig. 2 reveals that in the IID scenario, these methods achieve similar performance. For three heterogeneous scenarios on the FMNIST dataset, as shown in Fig. 3 (a), (b), and (c), respectively, the proposed method achieves performance that is the most similar to that with full client participation. Moreover, it exhibits faster convergence speed and superior test accuracy compared to prior works. Notably, there is an approximate 20%percent2020\% improvement in the 1SPC scenario and an 8%percent88\% improvement in the 2SPC and Dir scenarios. Similar trends are also observed for the CIFAR-10 dataset.

V-B2 Time Overhead Analysis

We evaluate the time overhead of the proposed client selection strategy, and the results are presented in Table I. The time overhead analysis is conducted on the FMNIST dataset under the 1SPC scenario, with similar observations across other scenarios. In Table I, the first row focuses on the time solely for client selection within a communication round, while the second row denotes the overall time required for a complete communication round, including client selection, local updates, and global aggregation.

First, examining the time solely for client selection, our proposed method exhibits only a marginal increase (less than 0.4ms) compared to existing methods. This increment is acceptable in most real applications. In addition, the time required for client selection (about 0.5ms) is almost negligible compared to the total time required to complete a communication round (about 2000ms). This highlights that the majority of time is allocated to local updates within clients. Second, examining the time required to complete a round, our proposed strategy imposes only a modest additional computational time (about 400 ms) compared to existing approaches. This is primarily because evaluating the distance Disti,j‚Äã(t)subscriptDistùëñùëóùë°\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t) in Eq. (5) is time-consuming, especially when the dimension of ‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}) is high. The time overhead can be reduced by employing a more efficient method for calculating distances in high-dimensional gradient space. Nevertheless, the marginal increase in time for the proposed strategy is justified when considering its superior performance in client selection.

V-B3 Visualization of Client Selection Strategy

We provide visualizations of the selected clients to offer an interpretable analysis of our proposed strategy. As shown in Fig. 4, in the 1SPC scenario on the FMNIST dataset, baseline methods typically select two or more clients from the same cluster. In contrast, the proposed LongFed, as shown in 4 (e), selects one client from each cluster, which effectively approximates the data distribution of the full client set. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 4 (f), it chooses a diverse subset of clients in the multi-round selection, adhering to Principle II.

The results in the 2SPC scenario are illustrated in Fig. 5, where the clustering pattern is not evident. For baseline methods, the circles around selected clients often overlap and cover only a minority of clients. However, in our proposed method, as shown in Fig. 5 (e), these circles cover the majority of clients. This suggests that the selected clients provide a better approximation of the full client set compared to the baseline approaches. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 5 (f), the strategy selects a diverse subset of clients across multiple rounds, satisfying Principle II. Visualization results of other scenarios are provided in the supplementary file.

V-C Individual Fairness Analysis

We analyze the proposed individual fairness in terms of the trade-off factor VùëâV, the similarity measure œµitalic-œµ\epsilon, and the probability difference measure Œ¥ùõø\delta. The results are illustrated using the 2SPC scenario on the CIFAR-10 dataset, and similar trends are observed for other scenarios. The random selection strategy is chosen as the baseline because it selects clients randomly and without bias. The impact of these parameters is assessed through two metrics: test accuracy and the standard deviation of the selection probability pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} between clients with similar data distributions, denoted as œÉ‚Äã(t)ùúéùë°\sigma(t). Trade-Off Factor VùëâV. We vary the value of VùëâV from 0.00.00.0, 0.40.40.4, 0.60.60.6, and 1.01.01.0, and present the results in Fig. 6. First, we observe that the proposed method with these four values converges faster than the random strategy and achieves better performance. Among them, V=0.6ùëâ0.6V=0.6 yields the best test accuracy. This suggests that the individual fairness constraint improves the overall performance. Second, the random strategy achieves the lowest standard deviation œÉ‚Äã(t)ùúéùë°\sigma(t). The proposed method exhibits significantly larger œÉ‚Äã(t)ùúéùë°\sigma(t) when V=1.0ùëâ1.0V=1.0. This is because when V=1.0ùëâ1.0V=1.0, our proposed method prioritizes minimizing the estimation error in Eq. (2) and neglects the fairness constraint. Furthermore, the standard deviation œÉ‚Äã(t)ùúéùë°\sigma(t) decreases significantly when V‚â§0.6ùëâ0.6V\leq 0.6. It indicates that the constraint in Eq. (7) indeed enhances the system fairness.

Similarity Measure œµitalic-œµ\epsilon. We vary the value of œµitalic-œµ\epsilon across 0.050.050.05, 0.10.10.1, 0.20.20.2, and 0.30.30.3, and observe the corresponding test accuracy and standard deviation, as presented in Fig. 7. First, the results on test accuracy indicate that the proposed method outperforms the random strategy consistently across these œµitalic-œµ\epsilon values. On the other hand, a larger œµitalic-œµ\epsilon in the proposed method corresponds to a smaller standard deviation. Specifically, the results are comparable to the random selection strategy when œµ>0.05italic-œµ0.05\epsilon>0.05, and even surpass it when œµ=0.3italic-œµ0.3\epsilon=0.3. This is attributed to the fact that a larger œµitalic-œµ\epsilon enforces more clients to follow the fairness constraint, thus the standard deviation obtained through the proposed strategy gets closer to the random selection strategy.

Probability Difference Measure Œ¥ùõø\delta. We vary the value of Œ¥ùõø\delta across 0.010.010.01, 0.10.10.1, 0.150.150.15, and 0.20.20.2, and observe the corresponding test accuracy and standard deviation, as presented in Fig. 8. The results indicate that the proposed method consistently performs better than the random selection strategy across these Œ¥ùõø\delta values in terms of test accuracy. Moreover, a smaller Œ¥ùõø\delta in the proposed method corresponds to a smaller standard deviation. This is because a smaller Œ¥ùõø\delta narrows the range of probability difference between clients with similar distributions, resulting in a smaller standard deviation.

VI Conclusion

In our work, we introduce a novel long-term client selection approach for federated learning, aiming to emulate the optimization trajectory achieved by full client participation. We establish two guiding principles to steer the client selection process effectively. We formulate the client selection problem as a long-term optimization task, where the objective is to minimize the estimation error in gradient space between the selected subset of clients and the full client set. Besides, we impose the individual fairness constraint to ensure similar selection frequencies among clients with similar data distributions. Leveraging Lyapunov optimization techniques from control theory, we transform this problem and propose a greedy algorithm to find solutions efficiently. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed strategy closely approximates the performance achieved under full client participation, with significant improvements over previous methods in terms of both accuracy and fairness. Additionally, our method exhibits efficiency by incurring minimal time overhead, which is often negligible when compared to local training duration.

VII Additional Details of The Proposed Optimization Function

VII-A Proof of Theorem 1

Proof.

Following the analysis in [32], based on the mapping Œæt:‚Ñï‚Üíùïät:superscriptùúâùë°‚Üí‚Ñïsuperscriptùïäùë°\xi^{t}:\mathbb{N}\rightarrow\mathbb{S}^{t} that assigns each client i‚àà‚Ñïùëñ‚Ñïi\in\mathbb{N} to a client j‚ààùïätùëósuperscriptùïäùë°j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}, we have

‚àëi‚àà‚Ñï‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)subscriptùëñ‚Ñï‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}) =‚àëi‚àà‚Ñï[‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àí‚àáfŒæt‚Äã(i)‚Äã(ùíòt)+‚àáfŒæt‚Äã(i)‚Äã(ùíòt)]absentsubscriptùëñ‚Ñïdelimited-[]‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°‚àásubscriptùëìsuperscriptùúâùë°ùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°‚àásubscriptùëìsuperscriptùúâùë°ùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\quad=\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\left[\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{\xi^{t}(i)}(\bm{w}^{t})+\nabla f_{\xi^{t}(i)}(\bm{w}^{t})\right] (35)
=‚àëi‚àà‚Ñï[‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àí‚àáfŒæt‚Äã(i)‚Äã(ùíòt)]+‚àëj‚ààùïätŒ∏jt‚Äã‚àáfj‚Äã(ùíòt).absentsubscriptùëñ‚Ñïdelimited-[]‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°‚àásubscriptùëìsuperscriptùúâùë°ùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°subscriptùëósuperscriptùïäùë°superscriptsubscriptùúÉùëóùë°‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\quad=\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\left[\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{\xi^{t}(i)}(\bm{w}^{t})\right]+\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t}).

Subtracting and taking the norm of the both sides, we have

‚Äñ‚àëi‚àà‚Ñï‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àí‚àëj‚ààùïätŒ∏jt‚Äã‚àáfj‚Äã(ùíòt)‚Äñ‚â§‚àëi‚àà‚Ñï‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àí‚àáfŒæt‚Äã(i)‚Äã(ùíòt)‚Äñ.normsubscriptùëñ‚Ñï‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°subscriptùëósuperscriptùïäùë°superscriptsubscriptùúÉùëóùë°‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptùíòùë°subscriptùëñ‚Ñïnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°‚àásubscriptùëìsuperscriptùúâùë°ùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\big{\|}\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}\leq\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\big{\|}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{\xi^{t}(i)}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}. (36)

The upper bound is minimized when Œætsuperscriptùúâùë°\xi^{t} assigns each client i‚àà‚Ñïùëñ‚Ñïi\in\mathbb{N} to the client in the subset ùïätsuperscriptùïäùë°\mathbb{S}^{t} that has the highest similarity in the gradient space. That is,

Œæt‚Äã(i)‚ààargminj‚ààùïät‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àí‚àáfj‚Äã(ùíòt)‚Äñ,superscriptùúâùë°ùëñsubscriptargminùëósuperscriptùïäùë°norm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\xi^{t}(i)\in\text{argmin}_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\big{\|}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}, (37)

Therefore, we have

minŒ∏jt‚Å°‚Äñ‚àëi‚àà‚Ñï‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àí‚àëj‚ààùïätŒ∏jt‚Äã‚àáfj‚Äã(ùíòt)‚Äñ‚â§‚àëi‚àà‚Ñïminj‚ààùïät‚Å°‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àí‚àáfj‚Äã(ùíòt)‚Äñ,subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúÉùëóùë°normsubscriptùëñ‚Ñï‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°subscriptùëósuperscriptùïäùë°superscriptsubscriptùúÉùëóùë°‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptùíòùë°subscriptùëñ‚Ñïsubscriptùëósuperscriptùïäùë°norm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùíòùë°‚àásubscriptùëìùëósuperscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\min_{\theta_{j}^{t}}\big{\|}\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}\leq\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\min_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\big{\|}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}, (38)

which completes the proof. ‚àé

VIII Additional Details of The Convergence Analysis

VIII-A Proof of Theorem 4

Proof.

Our theoretical analysis is based on the FedAvg [1] method, and it can also be extended to other federated optimization methods. To align with the approach in [42], we unify the epochs of local training in clients and communication rounds for parameter transmission between the server and clients into a single dimension, indexed by t=s‚ÄãE+kùë°ùë†ùê∏ùëòt=sE+k. Here, sùë†s denotes the index of the current communication round, Eùê∏E is the number of local epochs in a communication round, and k‚àà[1,E‚àí1]ùëò1ùê∏1k\in[1,E-1]. If tùë°t is divisible by Eùê∏E (indicated as t‚à£Econditionalùë°ùê∏t\mid E), it signifies the communication step where the server aggregates the model parameters from the selected clients. Otherwise, it represents a local training step for clients.

To show the convergence, we introduce an auxiliary variable ùíóitsuperscriptsubscriptùíóùëñùë°\bm{v}_{i}^{t} to signify the immediate result of a single stochastic gradient descent (SGD) step in local updates. That is,

IX Additional Details of Experiment

IX-A Experimental Settings

Following [18], for the FMNIST dataset, we employ a multilayer perceptron with two hidden layers as the global model, where the number of units in the two hidden layers is 64 and 30, respectively. Additionally, we set the number of local epochs to 3, the local batch size to 64, and the learning rate to 0.0050.0050.005. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, the architecture of the global model is a convolutional neural network (CNN) with three convolutional layers having 32, 64, and 64 kernels, respectively. All kernels are designed with the size 3√ó3333\times 3. Besides, the outputs of the convolutional layers are fed into an MLP layer with 64 units. We set the number of local epochs to 5, the local batch size to 128, and the learning rate to 0.05.

IX-B Visualization of Client Selection Strategy

The visualization results in Fig. 9 for the FMNIST dataset under the Dir scenario are similar to the 2SPC scenario. Specifically, in Fig. 9 (b)-(d), the circles around selected clients for baseline methods often overlap and cover only a minority of clients. Moreover, as depicted in Fig. 9 (e), the clients selected by our proposed method effectively cover the majority of remaining clients. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 9 (f), the strategy selects different clients in different rounds, adhering to the fairness constraint.

For further insights, we provide visualizations for the CIFAR-10 dataset in the 1SPC, 2SPC, and Dir scenarios in Fig. 10, Fig. 11, and Fig. 12, respectively. The conclusions drawn from the CIFAR-10 dataset align with those from the FMNIST dataset.
